s.gd: Bha Màiread ag obair leis am vacuum agus an toiseach cha do dh’fhairich i an gnogadh idir.
s.en: Margaret was working with the vacuum and at first she did not hear the knocking at all.

s.gd: ’Se seann vacuum a bha ann agus nuair bhitheadh i ag obair leis bha e a’ dèanamh a leithid a dh’fhuaim ’s gu saoileadh tu nach cluinneadh i bomb a’ dol dheth a-muigh air an t-sràid.
s.en: I was an old vacuum and when she would be working with it it was making the kind of noise that you would think that she would hear a bomb going off outside in the street.

s.gd: Ach b’e a’ chiad vacuum a bha aice riamh agus bha seòrsa de thaobh aice ris.
s.en: But it was the first vacuum she had ever had and she had a kind of liking for it.

s.gd: Chan ann le toileachas sam bith a dh’fhosgail i an doras oir dh’aithnich i gnogadh Seònaid Uilleim on ath thaigh agus cha robh sannt sam bith aice air bruidhinn ri Seònaid aig an àm.
s.en: It was not with any pleasure that she opened the door because she had recognised the knocking of William’s Janet from the next house and she had absolutely no desire to speak to Janet at that time.

s.gd: “Thig a-staigh,” arsa Màiread agus i a’ feuchainn ri a bhith a’ coimhead sìos air Seònaid.
s.en: “Come inside,” said Margaret, trying to be looking down on Janet.

s.gd: ’Se boireannach mòr foghainteach a bha innte agus coltas oirre nach cuireadh nì fon ghrèin eagal oirre.
s.en: She was a big strong woman and had the appearance that nothing under the sun would frighten her.

s.gd: Cha ghabhadh i oirre uair sam bith gun tàinig i a dh’aon sgrìob a choimhead ort.
s.en: She would never pretend that she had come of one trip to see you.

s.gd: Thug i sùil air am vacuum ach cha duirt i guth.
s.en: She looked at the vacuum but she did not say a word.

s.gd: Bha seo na chomharradh gu robh i ann an trim meadhonach math.
s.en: This was a sign that she was in a moderately good mood.

s.gd: Is ainneamh a chitheadh i am vacuum nach canadh i, “Cha d’fhuair thu cuidhteas an rud sin fhathast.”
s.en: It is rare that she would see the vacuum and she would not say, “You haven’t got rid of that thing yet.”

s.gd: Bha vacuum briagha ùr aice fhèin.
s.en: She herself had a beautiful new vacuum.

s.gd: “Uill,” arsa Seònaid, “Tha mi deiseil tràth an-diugh.”
s.en: “Well,” said Janet, “I am ready early today.”

s.gd: “Dh’èirich mi aig seachd agus dhall mi air an taigh cho luath ’s a dh’fhalbh Tormod a dh’obair.
s.en: “I got up at seven and I attacked the house as soon as Norman left for work.

s.gd: “Seadh, gabhaidh mi cupa,” ars ise nuair a thathainn Màiread tì oirre.
s.en: “Yes, I will take a cup,” she said when Margaret offered her tea.

s.gd: Bha fhios aig Màiread a-nis nach bitheadh i fada gus an tòisicheadh i air na burglars.
s.en: Margaret know now that it would not be long until she would start on the burglars.

s.gd: Bha an còmhnaidh cuspair air choreigin aig Seònaid air am bitheadh i a’ leantainn gus am bitheadh a h-uile duine ach i-fhèin seachd sgìth dheth.
s.en: Janet always had some topic or other on which she was following until everybody but herself would be sick and tired of it.

s.gd: An-dràsda, ’se na burglars a bha ann.
s.en: Now, it was the burglars.

s.gd: O chionn seachdain no dhà chaidh briseadh a-staigh a dhèanamh air dà thaigh anns an nàbachd agus gnothaichean a ghoid asda.
s.en: One or two weeks ago, a burglary was done on two houses in the neighbourhood and things stolen from them.

s.gd: On àm sin cha do sguir Seònaid a bhruidhinn mu na burglars a h-uile uair a thachradh duine rithe.
s.en: From that time, Janet had not stopped talking about the burglars every time that somebody would happen upon her.

s.gd: “Uill, cha do thill iad tuilleadh,” ars ise, “ach cha leig iad a leas an taigh againne fheuchainn.
s.en: “Well, they haven’t returned again,” she said, “but they needn’t bother trying our house.”

s.gd: Tha deagh ghlas air an doras agus tha Tormod a’ cadal a h-uile oidhche leis a’ phòcair ri thaobh.
s.en: There is a good lock on the door and Norman sleeps every night with the poker by his side.

s.gd: Chan eil fhios agam ciamar a tha thusa a’ dèanamh an gnothach idir, a Mhàiread, ach ma tha eagal ort chan eil agad ach gnogadh.”
s.en: I don’t know how you are dealing with the matter at all, Margaret, but if you are afraid, you only have to knock.”

s.gd: Cha duirt Màiread guth.
s.en: Margaret said nothing.

s.gd: Chan èisdeadh Seònaid rithe ann.
s.en: Janet would not listen to her in it.

s.gd: Cha do leig i oirre an liuthad oidhche a dh’èirich i a dhèanamh cinnteach gu robh na dorsan agus na h-uinneagan glaiste agus i air chrith leis an eagal.
s.en: She did not disclose the many nights that she got up to make sure that the doors and the windows were locked, shaking with fear.

s.gd: Ach mu dheireadh thall chuir Seònaid crìoch air a sgeul agus air an tì.
s.en: But eventually Janet finished her story and her tea.

s.gd: “’S fheàrr dhomhsa falbh ged tha,” ars ise.
s.en: “I should leave anyway,” she said.

s.gd: “Bithidh gu leòr agadsa ri dhèanamh fhathast.”
s.en: “You will have enough to do still.”

s.gd: Leig Màiread osna nuair dhùin an doras air cùlaibh Seònaid.
s.en: Margaret let out a sigh when the door closed behind Janet.

s.gd: Nach tric a bha farmad aice ri Seònaid airson a’ bharail a bha aice oirre fhèin.
s.en: It was not often that she had ency of Janet for the opinion that she had of herself.

s.gd: “Bha mise math gu leòr nuair a bha Seumas agam ...
s.en: “I was good enough when I had James ...

s.gd: Ach cha dhèan seo an gnothach,” arsa Màiread rithe fhèin agus chum i oirre le obair an taighe.
s.en: But that won’t do the trick,” Margaret said to herself and she continued with the housework.

s.gd: Nuair a bha i deiseil anns an rùm cadail stob i am vacuum anns a’ bhocsa aige air cùl a’ chùirtein anns a’ phreasa bheag agus thòisich i air cur uimpe airson a dhol a-mach gu na bùthan.
s.en: When she was done in the bedroom, she pushed the vacuum in its box behind the curtain in the little press and she started to get ready to go out to the shops.

s.gd: Dhùisg Màiread aig uair sa’ mhadainn an là’rna mhàireach agus fallas oirre.
s.en: Margaret woke up at one o’clock in the morning the next day, sweating.

s.gd: Bha bruthainn ann agus bha solas na gealaich a’ deàrrsadh tron uinneig air a cùlaibh agus a’ dèanamh pàtran buidhe air a’ bhalla aig ceann na leapa.
s.en: There was sultry heat and the moonloght was shining through the window behind her and making a yellow pattern on the wall at the head of the bed.

s.gd: Shad i dhith a’ chuibhrig ach cha tigeadh cadal ga h-ionnsaigh agus mu dheireadh laigh i a’ coimhead a’ phàtrain a bha a’ ghealach a’ dèanamh air a’ bhalla agus a’ feuchainn ri a h-inntinn a dhèanamh suas airson èirigh agus cupa tì a dhèanamh dhi fhèin.
s.en: She threw off the cover but sleep would not come towards her and eventually she lay down looking at the patterm that the moon was making on the wall and trying to make up her mind to get up and make a cup of tea for herself.

s.gd: Bu bheag oirre riamh a bhith a’ dùsgadh feadh na h-oidhche.
s.en: She had always disliked waking up throughout the night.

s.gd: Bhiodh rudan a thachair feadh an latha agus uaireannan eile a’ tighinn a-staigh oirre.
s.en: Things that happened during the day and at other times would be coming into her mind.

s.gd: Rudan beaga grànda a dhìochuimhnich i mun deidhinn nuair bha i trang.
s.en: Little ugly things that she had forgotten about when she was busy.

s.gd: Bha i a’ tuiteam na cadal a-rithist nuair shaoil i gun dh’fhairich i brag.
s.en: She was falling asleep again when she became aware that she had heard a crash.

s.gd: Dh’èirich i na suidhe anns an leabaidh agus dh’fhan i greis mar sin ach cha chuala i càil ach buillean trom a cridhe fhèin.
s.en: She sat up in the bed and she waited a while like that but she did not hear anything but the heavy beats of her own heart.

s.gd: Shaoil i gu robh i greis mhòr mar sin na suidhe ag èisdeachd.
s.en: She thought that she was sat like that for a long time listening.

s.gd: Smaoinich i air èirigh ach nuair nach cuala i an còrr tuilleadh laigh i sìos a-rithist agus tharrainn i aodach na leapa suas ma cluasan.
s.en: She thought of getting up but when she didn’t hear any more she lay down again and she pulled the bedclothes up around her ears.

s.gd: Bha i dìreach gu tuiteam seachad nuair dh’fhairich i an ath bhrag.
s.en: She was just about to fall past when she heard another crash.

s.gd: Leum i na suidhe.
s.en: She sat up quickly.

s.gd: Bha buillean a cridhe cho trom ’s gu robh dùil aice gum briseadh e mach às a com.
s.en: The beats of her heart were so heavy hat she expected that it would break out from her chest.

s.gd: An uairsin laigh a sùil air bonn an dorais far am faiceadh i sreath de sholas na gealaich a bha tighinn tro uinneig bhig anns an doras a-muigh, agus bhrùchd fallas a-mach air a mala.
s.en: Then her eye settled on the bottom of the door where she would see a stream of moonlight that was coming through a little window in the outside door, and sweat rushed out on her brow.

s.gd: Chunnaic i faileas a’ dol seachad air bonn an dorais.
s.en: She saw a shadow going past the bottom of the door.

s.gd: Dh’fheuch i ri sgairt a leigeil aiste ach cha tigeadh guth às a h-amhaich.
s.en: She tried to let out a shriek but no voice would come from her throat.

s.gd: Dh’èirich i air a cois ach bha a leithid a chrith na casan ’s gun lùb iad fòidhpe.
s.en: She rose up onto her feet but a kind of shaking was in her legs so that they bent under her.

s.gd: Chaidh aice air snàigeil a-staigh don phreasa bheag air cùl a’ chùirtein agus dh’fhan i na crùban an sin.
s.en: She managed to crawl inside the little press behind the curtain and she waited, crouched, there.

s.gd: De dhèanadh i?
s.en: What would she do?

s.gd: Cha robh càil ri chluinntinn a-nis ach a cridhe fhèin a’ dèanamh a leithid a dh’fhuaim ’s gu saoileadh tu gun cluinneadh duine aig ceann shìos an taighe e.
s.en: There was nothing to be heard now but her own heart making the sort of noise that you would think that someone would hear it at the far end of the house.

s.gd: An uairsin dh’fhairich i fuaim a dh’aithnich i, fuaim doras an rùm cadail ga fhosgladh air a shocair.
s.en: Then she heard a noise that she recognised, the sound of the bedroom door being opened carefully.

s.gd: Cha b’urrainn i èigheach ann.
s.en: She was unable to cry out.

s.gd: Bha i mar gu robh i ga tachdadh.
s.en: She was as if she were being strangled.

s.gd: Chrùb i nas fhaide staigh ris a’ bhalla agus bhuail a làmh air rudeigin, plug am vacuum.
s.en: She curled closer in to the wall and her hand hit on something, the plug of the vacuum.

s.gd: Bha i an leithid a chabhaig a’ dol a-mach ’s gun d’ fhàg i anns an toll e.
s.en: She had been in such a hurry going out that she had left it in the socket.

s.gd: Dh’fhairich i casan an duine a’ coiseachd gu socair a-null don leabaidh.
s.en: She heard the man’s feet walking carefully across to the bed.

s.gd: An uairsin, agus i gu dol seachad leis an eagal thàinig badhg a-staigh oirre — gus an latha seo chan eil fhios aice ciamar.
s.en: Then, with her nearly dying with fear, a whim came over her – until this day she does not know how.

s.gd: Chuir i mach a làmh agus chuir i air am vacuum.
s.en: She sent out her hand and put it on the vacuum.

s.gd: An ath rud chaidh fois na h-oidhche bhriseadh le fuaim uabhasach am vacuum agus sgairtean Màiread a’ tighinn glè fhaisg air ann an neart.
s.en: The next thing the quiet of the night was broken with a terrible noise of the vacuum and Margaret’s shrieks coming very near it in strength.

s.gd: Chunnaic dithis phoileasman an càr a-muigh air an t-sràid, dithis dhaoine a’ leum a-mach air doras taigh Màireid mar gu robh an deamhain às an dèidh.
s.en: Two policemen saw the car outside on the street, two men running out the door of Maragert’s house as though the devil were after them.

s.gd: Cha b’fhada gus an robh iad aca.
s.en: It was not long until they had them.

s.gd: An ath latha bha Màiread na suidhe a-rithist ag èisdeachd ri Seònaid a’ bruidhinn mu na burglars.
s.en: The next day Margaret was sat again listening to Janet speaking abouts the burglars.

s.gd: “Tha mi a’ smaoineachadh, a Mhàiread,” ars ise, “gur e an Sealbh fhèin a thug air am vacuum a dhol dheth mar rinn e.
s.en: “I think, Margaret,” she said, “that it was Providence itself that made the vacuum go off as it did.

s.gd: Nan robh thusa air a dhol tro na chaidh sinne chan fhaigheadh tu seachad air.”
s.en: If you had gone through what we went through, you would not have got past it.”

s.gd: Cha duirt Màiread guth.
s.en: Margaret did not say a word.

s.gd: Bha i a’ smaoinechadh air an t-sealladh a chunnaic i nuair thug na poileasmain gu taigh Seònaid i aig dà uair sa’ mhadainn airson gun coimheadadh iad às a dèidh.
s.en: She thought of the view that she had seen when the policemen had taken her to Janet’s house at two o’clock in the morning so that they could look after her.

s.gd: Bha an doras a-muigh fosgailte agus nuair chaidh iad a-staigh don rùm-chadal fhuair iad Seònaid agus an duine air an ceangal ri casan na leapa.
s.en: The outside door was opened and when they went inside to the bedroom they found Janet and the man tied to the legs of the bed.

s.gd: Cha mhòr nach tàinig gàire air Mairead nuair chuimhnìch i air a’ choltas a bha air aodann Seònaid — agus an clobhd-soithichean air a cheangal ma beul airson a cumail sàmhach!
s.en: A smile nearly came to Margaret when she remembered the expression that was on Janet’s face – and the dish-cloth tied around her mouth to keep her quiet!
